hints_html:
What is the definition of the linear approximation to a function \(f(x)\) at the point \(a\)?

The linear approximation, \(L(x)\), to a function, \(f(x)\), at the point \(a\), is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a).\end{aligned}\]

sols_html:
The linear approximation, \(L(x)\), to a function, \(f(x)\), at the point \(a\), is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a).\end{aligned}\]

From the information given we can write the linear approximation to the function \(f(x) = x^{1/3}\) at \(a = 8\) as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} L(x) &= 8^{1/3} + \frac{1}{3}8^{-2/3}(x - 8) \\ &= 2 + \frac{1}{12}(x - 8).\end{aligned}\]

Thus, the linear approximation gives us the approximate value for \((7.5)^{1/3}\):

\[\begin{aligned} (7.5)^{1/3} \approx L(7.5) &= 2 + \frac{1}{12}(7.5 - 8) \\ &= 2 - \frac{1}{24} \\ &= \frac{47}{24}.\end{aligned}\]
